column1: Petaluma  is a city in Sonoma County
column2: part of the North Bay sub-region of the San Francisco Bay Area
column3: located 37 mi (60 km) north of San Francisco. Its population was 57
column4: 941 according to the 2010 Census.The Rancho Petaluma Adobe
column5: located in Petaluma
column6: is a National Historic Landmark. Its construction started in 1836 by order of General Mariano Guadalupe Vallejo
column7: then Commandant of the San Francisco Presidio. It was the center of a 66
column8: 000 acre (270-km2) ranch stretching from Petaluma River to Sonoma Creek. The adobe is considered one of the best preserved buildings of its era in Northern California.

column1: Petaluma is a transliteration of the Coast Miwok phrase péta lúuma which means hill backside. Péta Lúuma was originally the name of a Miwok village located near the present day borders of the city of Petaluma.

column2: historic city center which includes many buildings that survived the 1906 San Francisco earthquake.

column1: The Coast Miwok resided in southern Sonoma County
column2: and Péta Lúuma was originally the name of a Miwok village east of the Petaluma River. A number of other Coast Miwok villages were also located in and around what is now Petaluma; Wotoki
column3: immediately to the south of the village of Petaluma
column4: on the opposite side of the river
column5: Etem
column6: Likatiut
column10: just north of what are now the city limits of Petaluma.The Petaluma area was part of a 66
column11: 000 acre (270 km2) 1834 Mexican land grant by Governor Jose Figueroa to Mariano Guadalupe Vallejo called Rancho Petaluma. In 1836
column12: Vallejo ordered construction of his Rancho Petaluma Adobe a ranch house in Petaluma
column13: which his family often used as a summer home
column14: while he resided in the neighboring town of Sonoma. Vallejo's influence and Mexican control in the region began to decline after Vallejo's arrest during the Bear Flag Revolt in 1846.

column1: Pioneers moved to Petaluma from the eastern United States after James Marshall found gold in the Sierra Nevada in 1848. The town's position on the Petaluma River in the heart of productive farmland was critical to its growth during the 19th and early 20th centuries. Sailing scows
column2: such as the scow schooner Alma (1892)
column3: and steamers plied the river between Petaluma and San Francisco
column4: carrying agricultural produce and raw materials to the burgeoning city of San Francisco during the California Gold Rush.

column1: There were brothels downtown along Petaluma Boulevard
column2: which used to be the main thoroughfare until U.S. Highway 101 was constructed in the 1950s.

column1: The Sonoma County Bank Building was the home of the Baker Creek Heirloom Seed Company and the Petaluma Seed Bank for a time. It was built in 1926.Petaluma soon became known for its grain milling and chicken processing industries
column2: which continue to the present as a smaller fraction of its commerce. At one time
column3: Petaluma was known as the "Egg Capital of the World
column4: sparking such nicknames as Chickaluma". Petaluma hosted the only known poultry drugstore and is the place where the egg incubator was invented by Lyman Byce in 1879. Petaluma is also where Randall Smith founded Mesa/Boogie (also known as Mesa Engineering)
column5: which manufactures high quality guitar and bass guitar amplification.

column1: One of the largest historic chicken processing plants still stands in the central area of town; this 1930s brick building is no longer used for the chicken industry
column2: but is being evaluated for preservation and change of use. Even though it is no longer known as the Egg Capital of the World
column3: Petaluma maintains a strong agricultural base today with dairy farms
column5: vineyards
column6: and berry and vegetable farms.

column1: According to the Army Museum at the Presidio
column3: Petaluma was relatively unharmed during the San Francisco earthquake of April 18
column5: due to significant stable bedrock underlying the region.  As one of the few communities in the region left standing after the earthquake
column6: Petaluma was the staging point for most Sonoma County rescue and relief efforts.Petaluma is today the location of many distinguished
column7: well-preserved pre-1906 buildings and Victorian homes on the western side of the river.  The downtown area has suffered many river floods over the years and during the Depression commerce declined. A lack of funds prevented the demolition of the old homes and buildings. In the 1960s there was a counter-culture migration out of San Francisco into Marin County and southern Sonoma County
column8: looking for inexpensive housing in a less urban environment. The old Victorian
column9: Queen Anne and Eastlake style houses were restored. Historic iron-front buildings in the downtown commercial district were also rescued. Traffic and new home development for the most part was rerouted to the east of downtown by the construction of the 101 freeway. The downtown Petaluma Historic Commercial District is on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: The first official airmail flight took place in 1911
column2: when Fred Wiseman carried a handful of mail from Petaluma to Santa Rosa
column3: including letters from Petaluma postmaster John E. Olmstead and Petaluma's mayor. Wiseman's plane ended up in the National Air and Space Museum.There was a substantial influx of Jewish residents
column4: starting during World War I. This community formed around shared socialist ideals
column5: as well as religious and cultural ties; this is depicted in the movie A Home on the Range (2002).

column1: With its large stock of historic buildings
column2: Petaluma has been used as the filming location for numerous movies set in the 1940s
column4: and '60s (see list of movies below). The historic McNear Building is a common film location.

column1: Petaluma pioneered the time-controlled approach to development. After Highway 101 was re-aligned as a freeway in 1955
column3: from 300 in 1969 to 900 in 1971. Because of the region's soaring population in the sixties
column4: the city enacted the "Petaluma Plan" in 1971. This plan limited the number of building permits to 500 annually for a five-year period beginning in 1972. At the same time Petaluma created a redbelt around the town as a boundary for urban expansion for a stated number of years. Similar to Ramapo
column5: New York
column6: a Residential Development Control System was created to distribute the building permits based on a point system conforming to the city's general plan to provide for low and moderate income housing and divide development somewhat equally between east and west and single family and multi-family housing.

column1: The stated objectives of Petaluma's time controlled growth management were to ensure orderly growth; to protect the city's small town character and surrounding green space; to provide a variety of housing choices; and to maintain adequate water supply and sewage treatment facilities.

The controlled development plan attracted national attention in 1975 when the city was taken to court by the Construction Industry Association. The city's restriction was upheld by the 9th Circuit Court in 1975 and the Supreme Court denied a Petition for Writ of Certiorari in 1976. This court ruling still forms the foundation for most local growth management ordinances in California.Despite this history of planned development
column2: the Petaluma City Council voted on April 13
column4: to eliminate the entire planning department and lay off the whole planning staff. Planning Division responsibilities were subsequently contracted out to the consulting firm Metropolitan Planning Group
column5: which re-hired some of the former planning staff and continues to operate planning services for the city.

column2: Petaluma was also known as Telecom Valley due to the telecom startup companies that seemed to multiply from one another
column3: and offer great riches for early stockholders and employees. Two success stories were that of Advanced Fibre Communications (AFC) (now Tellabs)
column5: which was purchased by Cisco. Some Cerent employees went on to purchase the Phoenix Theater
column6: a local entertainment venue
column7: which was once an opera house.

column1: The City has identified about two dozen buildings and districts as Petaluma landmarks.
Petaluma has a total area of 14.5 sq mi (37.6 km2). 14.4 sq mi (37.3 km2) of that is land and the remaining 0.1 sq mi (0.3 km2) is water. Water is 0.74% of the total area.
It is 32 miles (51 km) north of San Francisco.Petaluma is flanked by the unincorporated communities of Penngrove to the north and Lakeville to the south.
Petaluma is situated at the northernmost navigable end of the Petaluma River
column2: a tidal estuary that snakes southward to San Pablo Bay. Pollution levels in the river
column3: once considerable
column4: have improved in recent years. A significant amount of the city is in the river's flood plain
column5: which overflows its banks every few years
column6: particularly in the Payran neighborhood.Principal environmental noise sources are U.S. Route 101
column8: Washington Street and other major arteries. The number of residents that live in a zone of noise exposure greater than 60 CNEL is approximately 4

column1: Petaluma has a mild Mediterranean climate. Its dry summer is characterized by typically warm days and cool nights with a large degree of diurnal temperature variation. Summer mornings often start out foggy and chilly
column2: but the fog usually clears by midday or so
column3: giving way to clear skies and warmth for the remainder of the day. August is usually the warmest month
column4: with average daily temperatures ranging from 82 °F (28 °C) to 53 °F (12 °C). December is usually the coldest month
column5: with average daily temperatures ranging from 57 °F (14 °C) to 39 °F (4 °C). Winter is cool and rainy
column6: with frost occasionally occurring on clear nights.

column1: The National Weather Service's cooperative station in Petaluma had a record high temperature of 110 °F (43 °C) on June 2
column2: 1960. The record low temperature of 16 °F (−9 °C) was recorded on November 14
column5: 1932. The wettest year was 1998 with 45.93 inches (1
column6: 167 mm) and the driest year was 1976 with 8.29 inches (211 mm). The wettest month was February 1998 with 19.59 inches (498 mm). The most precipitation in 24 hours was 4.29 inches (109 mm) on December 27
column7: 2004. Although snow is rare in Petaluma
column9: as well as about 3 inches in January 2002.

column1: The U.S. Coast Guard operates Training Center Petaluma just outside Petaluma
column2: near Two Rock. It operates several of its class "A" and "C" schools at TRACEN Petaluma including the Electronics Technician (ET)
column3: Culinary Specialist (CS)
column5: Information Systems Technician (IT)
column6: Operation Specialist (OS)

column1: The Coast Guard also operates the Chief Petty Officer Academy at the TRACEN.  Academy trains senior non-commissioned officers (Chief Petty Officers) for both the U.S. Coast Guard and the U.S. Air Force.
The California National Guard operates an armed forces facility in Petaluma
Immediately to the southwest is Helen Putnam Regional Park
column2: accessible from Chileno Valley Road. This park of 216 acres (0.9 km2) has trails for hiking
column3: cycling and horseback riding and is one of two parks named in honor of former mayor Helen Putnam who served from 1965–1979; the other is Putnam Plaza on Petaluma Boulevard. Lying above the city of Petaluma on the northwest flank of Sonoma Mountain is the Fairfield Osborn Preserve
column4: a nature reserve with a diversity of native flora and fauna. Nearby to the southeast is Tolay Lake
column5: the site of prehistoric seasonal settlement by Miwok and Pomo tribes.

column1: Public schools are managed by the Petaluma City School District. There are two comprehensive high schools in Petaluma: Petaluma High School and Casa Grande High School
column2: whose athletic teams are known as the Trojans and Gauchos respectively. Casa Grande High School has a notable Academic Decathlon team
column3: which has represented Sonoma County for the last 27 years in the state-level competition. There is an annual football game between the two schools' teams known as the "Egg Bowl". The Game was suspended in 2011 for fights involving players and fans
column5: with Petaluma winning the game over Casa Grande
column6: 20–14. The two Petaluma public middle schools are Kenilworth Junior High School and Petaluma Junior High School.

column1: Petaluma is served by Petaluma Transit
column2: Golden Gate Transit and by Sonoma County Transit bus services. The Sonoma–Marin Area Rail Transit (SMART) rail line inaugurated service in August 2017 and serves Petaluma–Downtown station
column3: adjacent to the historic Northwestern Pacific Railroad depot near Washington Street. A second station
column5: is planned for future construction and service.

column1: The nearest major airports are San Francisco International Airport and Oakland International Airport
column2: Sonoma County Airport Express buses connect Petaluma with the aforementioned airports. General aviation is served by the Petaluma Municipal Airport. Also the Charles M. Schulz – Sonoma County Airport located north of Santa Rosa.

Petaluma held the world wrist wrestling championships from 1952 to 2003
column2: of which Hub "20 Pounds of Chicken a Day" Richmond won 19 times.  Hub is also known for his appearances at gyms for bending bars and also setting world lifiting records on any given day. (The championships were moved to Reno
column3: Nevada in 2004 due to a lack of sponsorship; the 2007 finals were held in Bulgaria.) In the comic strip Peanuts
column4: Snoopy aspired to be a champion arm-wrestler (or "wrist-wrestler
column5:
as they were then called) and was shown in a series of 1968 comic strips headed for Petaluma. (He was disqualified, as he had no thumb.)
Petaluma received national attention when 12-year-old Polly Klaas was kidnapped from her home at knifepoint on October 1, 1993, and later raped and murdered by Richard Allen Davis. The community pulled quickly together to publicize the disappearance and to form the Polly Klaas Foundation for missing and exploited children.
The Phoenix Theatre was the site of the punk/alt-rock band Sublime's last concert, the night before Brad Nowell's May 25, 1996 heroin overdose.
For the last 25 years Petaluma has played host to the World's Ugliest Dog Contest. Photos and results of the contest are typically reported worldwide. This annual event is held at the Sonoma-Marin Fair every Summer.
Petaluma hosts a Butter and Egg Days Parade" in April of each year
column6: celebrating its heritage as the "Egg Basket to the World" and dairy production.
